citation.article-title: Description of Paenisporosarcina quisquiliarum gen. nov., sp. nov., and reclassification of Sporosarcina macmurdoensis Reddy et al. 2003 as Paenisporosarcina macmurdoensis comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Paenisporosarcina quisquiliarum sp. nov.
Paenisporosarcina quisquiliarum (quis.qui.li.a′rum. L. gen. pl. n. quisquiliarum of wastes, referring to the isolation of the type strain from a municipal landfill site).
Displays the following properties in addition to those given in the genus description.
Cells are 2–4 μm long and form terminal endospores in swollen sporangia.
Colonies are cream-coloured, opaque and smooth with entire margins, 1–2 mm in diameter after 3 days of growth on TSBA.
Positive for arginine dihydrolase but negative for nitrate reduction, the Voges–Proskauer test and indole production.
Methyl red test is weakly positive.
Casein and starch are hydrolysed but xylan, xanthine, hypoxanthine, tyrosine, DNA, aesculin, gelatin and Tweens 20, 40, 60 and 80 are not.
Acid is produced from d-fructose, d-glucose, sucrose and d-galactose but not from l-arabinose, d-lactose, d-mannose, d-mannitol, l-rhamnose or d-xylose.
Other characteristics of the type strain are presented in Table 2.
The predominant menaquinones are MK-8 and MK-7, with minor quantities of MK-9, 10 and 11.

Fatty acids occurring in minor amounts are summed feature 4 (iso-C17 : 1 I and/or anteiso-C17 : 1 B), iso-C14 : 0, iso-C16 : 0, anteiso-C17 : 0, iso-C17 : 1ω10c, C16 : 0, iso-C17 : 0 and C14 : 0 (Table 1).
The polar lipid profile consists of the lipids given in the genus description plus three phospholipids (PL1, 3 and 4) and four unknown lipids (UL2, 3, 6 and 8).
The type strain, SK 55T (=MTCC7604T =JCM 14041T), was isolated from surface soil at a landfill site in Chandigarh, India.
